title: 2020 Exit Polls
text:
Project Type: Academic Group Project
Role: Lead Data Engineer
Responsibilities:

Guided a team of five to develop a predictive model for the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election using exit poll data.
Integrated logistic regression and random forest machine learning algorithms to predict the election outcome with an 85% accuracy rate.
Designed 20+ visualizations included in the final report.

Co-wrote Model Selection, Model Assumptions, and Results sections.

title: 2020 Exit Polls
text:
Project Type: Academic Group Project

Responsibilities:

Designed 20+ visualizations included in the final report.

Co-wrote Model Selection, Model Assumptions, and Results sections.

title: 2020 Exit Polls
text:
Abstract
This analysis aims to explore patterns in voting behavior using demographic and social attitude data. Utilizing logistic regression and random forest, we identified variables such as higher education levels, support for legal abortion, and belief in climate change as positively associated with voting Democratic, while better financial situations and Christian religious affiliations were negatively associated with voting Democratic. A model with 6 predictors was determined to be most applicable with a prediction accuracy of 85% and a ROC AUC score of 0.91. Future efforts should focus on standardizing survey questions to minimize the number of survey versions and and increase effective sample size and representation which will improve model accuracy.

title: Comparebnb
text:
Project Type: Academic Group Project
Role: Lead Web Designer
Responsibilities:

Collaborated in a team of six to investigate, critique, and publish the socioeconomic impacts of Airbnb on various cities.
Sole website architect spearheading website design, compatibility, and accessibility functions under a 16-hour deadline, ensuring full screen reader compatibility and a 0-error WAVE Evaluation score.
Responsible for Figures 1 and 10.

Co-wrote Datsets, Overview, and Conclusion pages.

title: Comparebnb

title: Comparebnb
text:
Summary
This research project was sparked by observations of the diverse relationships Airbnb establishes with various cities worldwide. In examining the impact of Airbnb’s operation on the socioeconomic aspects of London and New York City, this project aimed to uncover the key differences between these two influential cities. A particular interest was aimed in understanding how regulatory adjustments have influenced the supply and demand for short-term rentals and, subsequently, how these changes affect affordability and housing availability.

title: Comparebnb

Links
Project Site

title: About Oliver
text:
“Math is useless,” is what I thought growing up. Math lovers around me illustrate the “elegance” math brought, but none of that “elegance” stopped exploding water pipes or hills collapsing into a landslide. “It should have worked,” is what they would tell me. But it didn’t work.
After entering college, my math professor would chuckle at this story. He was not offended. Instead, he listened to each dilemma and highlighted what those math fanatics could and couldn’t know. Everyone would like to be 100% certain about everything, but accepting randomness is an inherent part of life. Randomness cannot be controlled, but we can try to understand its form and learn how to work with it. And thus, my math professor introduced me to statistics and data science. I no longer worked with abstract theories, but powerful tools that drive impactful decision making.
I have a nontraditional journey to higher education. I left school at 12 to train for a path I didn’t ultimately pursue, but it gave me many unique experiences and took me to many places across the globe such as Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Tahiti. In addition to my primary language, English, I picked up Mandarin and Cantonese while abroad, thus training strong adaptability and a keen eye for patterns.
Now, I specialize in using statistical methods through R, Python, and SQL to analyze data for informed data-driven decision making. My nontraditional global background gives me a flexible and resourceful problem-solving mindset, and my strong work ethic ensures I’m always willing to put in the effort to learn and grow.

title: Caffeine Island
text:
Project Type: Academic Group Project
Role: Data Analyst
Responsibilities:

Contributed in a team of seven to investigate the effects of caffeine consumption on human cognitive function, utilizing The Islands virtual simulation platform from The University of Queensland.
Determined a lack of improvement in cognitive function with caffeine consumption through Analysis of Variance (ANOVA).
Coordinated with team members to distribute caffeine doses and record cognitive function scores with minimal confounding factors.

Co-wrote Introduction section.

title: Caffeine Island
text:
Project Type: Academic Group Project
Role: Data Analyst
Responsibilities:

Contributed in a team of seven to investigate the effects of caffeine consumption on human cognitive function, utilizing The Islands virtual simulation platform from The University of Queensland.
Determined a lack of improvement in cognitive function with caffeine consumption through Analysis of Variance (ANOVA).
Coordinated with team members to distribute caffeine doses and record cognitive function scores with minimal confounding factors.

Co-wrote Introduction section.

title: Caffeine Island
text:
Abstract
Caffeine is one of the most commonly consumed legal drugs on the market, boasting various effects ranging from improved physiological capabilities to addictions. This investigative project challenges the validity of popular claims that caffeine can improve mental performance such as increasing a person’s attention span. A simulated island population was utilized to research the effects of caffeine with a Replicated Latin Square Design to experiment. 63 participants were selected to participate in the study and were assigned one of 3 levels of caffeine, and each participant underwent a 10-minute attention test before and after taking their assigned amount of caffeine. The differences in their test results were compared, and these differences found that caffeine did not have a significant effect on any participant’s attention test scores. Caffeine has many known practical and popular uses in consumer products, but it may not be suitable for maintaining a person’s attention span. Further research is recommended to ascertain caffeine’s exact benefits and drawbacks. As with any drug, caffeine should be consumed in moderation, and consumers using caffeine as a performance enhancer should ensure to consume caffeine for the appropriate tasks.

title: Caffeine Island

title: COVID City
text:
Project Type: Academic Group Project
Role: Editor
Responsibilities:

Collaborated in a team of six to investigate the economic impact of COVID-19 lockdown policies on New York City and Omaha.
Edited and formatted the project report adhering to IEEE .Rtex standards.
Compiled and edited project code to ensure reproducibility

Designed Figure 1: Histograms, included in the report.

title: COVID City
text:
Abstract
This report investigates the impact of COVID-19 lockdown policies on spending, and whether said policies impacted the economic recovery of a city. We chose to focus on New York City, New York, a state that enforced a mandatory lockdown, and Omaha, Nebraska, a state that did not issue any stay-at-home or complete lockdown orders. This report uses data from the Opportunity Insights data tracker, a non-partisan, not-for-profit organization located at Harvard University. In order to conduct this analysis, we created several time series plots and conducted t-tests using our chosen variables. We found that spending overall was significantly different in the two cities – spending in arts and entertainment decreased while grocery spending increased in New York City, and arts spending increased while grocery spending remained unaffected in Omaha. Our t-tests indicate a significant difference as well, with a p-value \(< 0.05\). In conjunction, our t-tests and time series plots both suggest a rejection of the null hypothesis, thus, we conclude that lockdown policies have an impact on spending. However, due to our limiting factors (mainly the confounding variables which occur due to the differences in population, primary industry, and other aspects of the two cities), we are unable to concretely determine the exact impact lockdown policies have. Still, we believe our analysis could result in useful contributions regarding policy decisions, namely the impact that national disasters may have on spending and potential areas of impact to focus on.
